title: Demystifying China's stock market : the hidden logic behind the puzzles
subject: Stock exchanges -- China
Bourse -- Chine
Stock exchanges
China
creator: Girardin, E. (Eric)$$QGirardin, E.
description: Mainstream research has rationalized China's stock market on the basis of paradigms such as the institutional approach, the efficient market hypothesis, and corporate valuation principles. The deviations from such paradigms have been analyzed as puzzles of China's stock market. Girardin and Liu explore to what extent, in the perspective of Chinese cultural and historical characteristics, far from being puzzles, these 'deviations' are rather the symptoms of a consistent strategy for the design, development and regulation of a government-dominated financial system. This book will help investors, observers and researchers understand the hidden logic of the design and functioning of China's modern stock market, taking a political economy view.
contents: Intro; Preface; Contents; About the Authors; List of Figures; List of Tables; Chapter 1: Demystifying China's Stock Market: The Hidden Logic Behind the Puzzles; 1.1 The Puzzles; 1.2 The Phoenix Market; 1.3 A Financial System Dominated by the Government; 1.4 A Speculative Market; 1.5 The Political Economy of an Incomplete Market; References; Chapter 2: What Does History Tell Us? The Roots of China's Modern Stock Market; 2.1 Introduction; 2.2 Corporations, Shareholding, and Early Financial Markets in Imperial China; 2.2.1 First Corporations and Shareholding Enterprises

2.2.2 Early Financial Markets2.3 Phoenix-like Markets; 2.3.1 Stock Market; 2.3.2 Bond Market; 2.4 The Rebirth of the Phoenix; 2.5 Lessons from China's Historical Experience; 2.5.1 Government Involvement; 2.5.2 Speculative Market Crashes; 2.6 Summary and Conclusions; References; Chapter 3: A Government-Dominated Financial System; 3.1 Introduction; 3.2 The Conundrum: How to Fit the Genie of the Stock Market Inside the Bottle of the Socialist Market Economy?; 3.3 Chinese-Style Privatization; 3.3.1 Multidimensional Ownership Reform; 3.3.2 Motivations for Stock Market Creation

3.3.3 Reform of State-Owned Banks3.4 Stock Market Development; 3.4.1 Institutional Evolution and Regulation; 3.4.2 Investors; 3.4.3 Intermediaries and Infrastructure; 3.4.4 Multi-layered Market; 3.4.5 Split-share Reform; 3.4.6 Opening Up; 3.5 Summary and Conclusions; References; Chapter 4: A Chinese Style Speculative Market; 4.1 Introduction; 4.2 Speculation; 4.2.1 What Attracts Investors to the Market?; 4.2.2 Bubbles; 4.3 Seasonality; 4.4 An Alphabet Soup of Premia; 4.4.1 From Trade to Financial Openness; 4.4.2 A and B Markets; 4.4.3 A and H Markets and Capital Controls

4.5 Summary and ConclusionsReferences; Chapter 5: The Political Economy of an Incomplete Market; 5.1 Introduction; 5.2 Corporate Governance Chinese Style; 5.2.1 Enforcement; 5.2.2 Concentration of Ownership; 5.2.3 IPO Quota System; 5.3 Multiple Principals and Price Informativeness; 5.4 Deconcentrated Multiple Principals of Listed SOEs; 5.5 Summary and Conclusions; References; Index
